title: Historical Stock Splits and Corporate Actions of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd

content.text: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd goes public with its Initial Public Offering.
Teva announces a 2-for-1 stock split, doubling the number of outstanding shares.
Teva acquires Sicor Inc., a global generic pharmaceuticals company, expanding its market presence.
Teva announces a 3-for-1 stock split, increasing the number of outstanding shares.

content.section: 2002: Acquisition of AstraZeneca's Generic Drug Business
content.text: Teva acquires AstraZeneca's generic drug business, further expanding its product portfolio.
Teva completes the acquisition of Ivax Corporation, enhancing its position as a leading generic pharmaceuticals company.
Teva announces a 2-for-1 stock split, doubling the number of outstanding shares.
Teva acquires Cephalon Inc., a biopharmaceutical company focused on specialty medicines.
Teva announces a 2-for-1 stock split, doubling the number of outstanding shares.
Teva completes the acquisition of Actavis Generics, significantly expanding its global reach in generic drugs.
Teva announces a 2-for-1 stock split, doubling the number of outstanding shares.
Teva implements a comprehensive restructuring plan to reduce costs and improve profitability.

news.headline: Teva Announces Changes to Executive Management Team
news.summary: TEL AVIV, Israel & PARSIPPANY, N.J., September 28, 2023--Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. (NYSE and TASE: TEVA) today announced changes to its leadership team. Sven Dethlefs, Executive Vice President, North America Commercial, will leave Teva on November 17, 2023, and Christine (Chris) Fox, who most recently served as Global President, Gene Therapies at Novartis will be the new head of Tevaâ€™s U.S. Commercial Business. news.headline: US judge overturns Eli Lilly's $176.5 million loss in Teva patent case
news.summary: Drugmaker Eli Lilly convinced a federal judge in Massachusetts on Tuesday to overturn a $176.5 million jury verdict for Teva Pharmaceutical that found Lilly's migraine drug Emgality infringed three patents related to Teva's rival drug Ajovy.  U.S. District Judge Allison Burroughs said in a post-trial ruling that the Teva patents covering the use of antibodies to inhibit headache-causing peptides were invalid.  "The Court does not reach this decision nor overturn a jury verdict lightly," Burroughs said.
